bestBHT.bht: Those who give in to their sinful desires and pursue a life centered around their own selfishness will ultimately reap destruction and decay. This corruption is both the consequence and the penalty of their sinful actions. They cannot deceive God, for He sees through their attempts to mock and deceive Him. On the other hand, those who cultivate a life directed by the Holy Spirit will reap the fruit of eternal life and find everlasting happiness and peace in the kingdom of God.

Henry Alford: he that (now) soweth,—is now sowing. unto,—with a view to. corruption—because the flesh is a prey to corruption.
with it all fleshly desires and practices come to nothing.
perhaps in the stronger sense of corruption (see 1 Cor. iii. 17; 2 Pet. ii. 12), destruction.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The flesh is devoted to selfishness.
Corruption is the fault, and corruption the punishment.
Men cannot mock God because they can deceive themselves.
Albert Barnes: He who makes use of his property to give indulgence to licentiousness, intemperance, and vanity."

Punishment, under the divine government, is commonly in the line of offences... Such, also, is often the punishment of luxurious living, of a pampered appetite, of gluttony, as well as of intemperate drinking.
He who follows the leadings and cultivates the affections which the Holy Spirit would produce... shall reap life everlasting.
Marvin Vincent: To his flesh...his own flesh...because the idea of personal, selfish desire is involved.
Corruption...primarily, destruction, ruin; but it also has the sense of deterioration, decay.
The Spirit...The Holy Spirit: not the higher nature of man.
John Calvin: To sow to the flesh, is to look forward to the wants of the present life, without any regard to a future life.
But he that soweth to the spirit...are said to sow whose views are directed more to heaven than to earth, and whose life is regulated by the desire of reaching the kingdom of God.
Though a reward had been a thousand times promised to works, yet it is not due but by fulfilling the condition of obeying the law perfectly; and how widely distant are we all from that perfection!
Philip Schaff: He that soweth unto (upon) his own flesh shall from the flesh reap corruption."
The soil of the flesh, that is of corrupt human nature, yields blighted and rotten fruit.
The soil of the Holy Spirit yields sweet and healthy fruit, even eternal happiness and peace.
Archibald T. Robertson: Corruption (φθοραν). For this old word from φθειρω, see on 1 Corinthians 15:42. The precise meaning turns on the context, here plainly the physical and moral decay or rottenness that follows sins of the flesh as all men know.
Nature writes in one's body the penalty of sin as every doctor knows.
Eternal life (ζωην αιωνιον). See on Matthew 25:46 for this interesting phrase so common in the Johannine writings.
John Gill: He that soweth to his flesh...shall of the flesh reap corruption.
But he that soweth to the Spirit...shall of the Spirit reap life everlasting.
In the use of such spiritual means...he shall attain to, and enjoy eternal happiness in the other world.
John Wesley: Shall hereafter of the flesh - Out of this very seed."
Shall of the Spirit — By the free grace and power of God, reap life everlasting.

bhtAttempts.bht: Those who give in to their sinful desires and pursue a life centered around their own selfishness will ultimately reap destruction and decay. This corruption is both the consequence and the penalty of their sinful actions. They cannot deceive God, for He sees through their attempts to mock and deceive Him. On the other hand, those who cultivate a life directed by the promptings of the Holy Spirit will reap the fruit of eternal life. By aligning their desires with the Spirit and living in accordance with His guidance, they will find everlasting happiness and peace in the kingdom of God.

Those who give in to their sinful desires and pursue a life centered around their own selfishness will ultimately reap destruction and decay. This corruption is both the consequence and the penalty of their sinful actions. They cannot deceive God, for He sees through their attempts to mock and deceive Him. On the other hand, those who cultivate a life directed by the Holy Spirit will reap the fruit of eternal life and find everlasting happiness and peace in the kingdom of God.

Those who sow in the realm of selfish desires will reap corruption and destruction, for the flesh is subject to decay and deterioration. They cannot deceive God, for He knows their true intentions and sees through their attempts to mock Him. In contrast, those who sow to the Spirit and align their lives with His guidance will reap the reward of eternal life. By following the path of the Spirit, they will experience everlasting happiness and find their place in the kingdom of God.

Those who pursue their own selfish desires and neglect the higher aspirations of the Spirit will ultimately face corruption and decay. This decay affects both their physical and moral well-being, leading to ruin and destruction. However, God cannot be mocked, as He sees through the façade of deceit. On the contrary, those who prioritize a life directed by the Holy Spirit will reap the fruits of eternal life. By aligning their desires with God's leading, they will find everlasting happiness and peace in His kingdom.

Those who sow seeds of selfishness and indulge in sinful desires will inevitably face the consequences of corruption and decay. This decay affects both their physical and moral well-being, leading to their ultimate destruction. However, it is impossible to deceive God, for He sees through all attempts to mock Him. In contrast, those who prioritize a life directed by the Holy Spirit will reap the rewards of eternal life. By aligning their desires with God's leading, they will find everlasting joy and peace in His kingdom.
